translated: Armfelt, Carl Gustaf, Baron, Papal Chamberlain. Born on March 28, 1866 in Stockholm to Captain Baron Carl A. and Lotten Cederbaum. Married in 1909 to Laureate de la Sorbonne, Officer of the French Legion of Honor, and Swedish Missionary Society MJozefa Hajdukiewicz de Pomian. Studied university in Innsbruck in 1906, received his law degree in Lund in 1898, and passed his chancery exam in 1900. He was a reserve officer in Bayern and Württemberg in 1894, in Schlesien in 1896, and traveled to France, Italy, Austria, and Poland in 1923, France, Switzerland, and Italy in 1925, France and Italy in 1928, and Belgium, Italy, and Poland in 1930. He was a member of the Swedish Public Export Association, secretary of the Swedish-Norwegian vice-consulate in Cardiff in 1902, secretary of the Swedish-Norwegian consulate in Riga from 1902 to 1906, clerk in the county council in 1901, member of the county council from 1911 to 1914, and Papal Chamberlain to His Holiness. He partially owned Kulla and other properties in Odensvi, Kalm. from 1914 and was the sole owner from 1932. He was the chairman of the Catholic Brigitta Association from 1910, chairman of the Concordia Catholica Association from 1910 to 1915, and inspector of the Odensvi lecture association from 1919 to 1944. He wrote "What Has Reformation Given Our People?" in 1917, "Around the Memory of Reformation" in 1918, "My Way to the Church" in 1920 (second edition in 1937, translated into Dutch and German), "Some Features of the Life of St. Francis of Sales" in 1924, and "Bishop Nils Hermansson" in 1931. He also contributed to The Catholic Encyclopedia in New York, the Lexicon of Education in Freiburg/Br., and Catholic journals in Sweden, Denmark, Norway, France, Germany, and the USA. He was decorated with the Papal Order St. Gregory in 1923.
